title: Iran to Breach Limits of Nuclear Pact, as U.S. to Send More Troops to Mideast
summary: Tehran said it would go above the 2015 cap on its stockpile of enriched uranium in 10 days, as Washington plans to send another 1,000 troops. Iran said it would exceed limits on its enriched-uranium stockpiles before the end of this month, as the U.S. said it would send an additional 1,000 troops to the Mideast in response to "hostile behavior" by Tehran.

title: Deutsche Bank Senior European Equities Banker Edward Sankey to Leave
summary: Pending cuts to equities, broader investment bank take increasing toll. Senior Deutsche Bank AG European equities banker Edward Sankey is leaving the bank after almost 15 years, as planned cuts to its beleaguered equities business and the broader investment bank increasingly take a toll, according to people close to the lender.

title: The Court's Unpolitical Conservatives
summary: Two rulings show the varieties of originalist legal interpretation.. Liberals warning of a sharp right turn on the Supreme Court following Justice Anthony Kennedy's retirement haven't been paying attention. The conservative Justices aren't voting in lockstep and are harder to predict than the Court's liberals, as two rulings Monday show.

title: Goldman Sachsonomics
summary: Gov. Phil Murphy wants to hit more people with a 10.75% tax rate.. An iron law of politics is never to trust a former Goldman Sachs executive who decides to run for elected office. Having made tens of millions of dollars at the financial giant, the former executive will typically have no qualms about raising taxes on others trying to become rich.

title: Iran, Europe and Trump
summary: Tehran's threat of a nuclear breakout shows its real intentions.. Iran said Monday that by the end of June it will exceed the limits it had agreed to on its stockpile of enriched uranium, and the question now is whether Europe will take this lying down. Exceeding the cap would violate the 2015 nuclear deal and force European leaders to decide if they want to acquiesce to Iran or join the U.S. in an effort to pressure Tehran to renegotiate the failed nuclear deal.

title: 'Hadestown' Tickets Sizzle After Show Wins Eight Tony Awards
summary: Out-of-town bookings for 'Oklahoma!' are becoming much easier to secure after its Tony wins, producer says. The Tony Awards may have come and gone. But a handful of shows are now reaping the financial rewards after winning honors at Broadway's big event a week ago.

title: A Reckoning With Martin Luther King
summary: Can America find grace and forbearance after shocking revelations about the civil-rights hero?. How can one understand the behavior unearthed by Martin Luther King Jr. biographer David Garrow? Mr. Garrow has reported, in sometimes pornographic detail, on King's assignations with some of the more than 40 women, single and married, with whom he is said to have had affairs. In the ugliest scene-difficult to comprehend or forgive-King stands by, and even laughs and offers advice, as a fellow minister rapes a woman. King is drunk, and he brags about it.

title: Has the Federal Reserve Lost Its Mojo?
summary: The central bank has less control over market interest rates today than at any time in its history.. When the Federal Open Market Committee's meeting concluded last month, reporters focused on the federal-funds rate, announcing that it would be held constant at 2.25% to 2.5%. Unnoticed by even the financial media, and unmentioned in the lead section of the FOMC's statement, was its decision to cut the interest rate the Federal Reserve pays on bank reserves-a rate that, unlike the fed-funds rate, still has a direct effect on the money supply. The Fed cut the rate paid on reserves because the market yield on one-year Treasurys had fallen below it, inducing banks to build up excess reserves. When banks expand reserve holdings, the money supply contracts-so the Fed was forced to act.

title: The Extinct Companies That Sponsored the Future
summary: The Bell System, TWA, A&P, Chun King-all feature in the 1964-65 World's Fair guidebook.. 'Businesses, like people, tend to get a little overly optimistic about what the future may bring," Justin Rivers said. As the weather warms up, his busy season is beginning. He's a tour guide; his company is called Untapped Cities, and he leads groups around Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, site of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair.

title: To Counter Beijing, the Best Option Is the G-7
summary: China will likely bypass whatever the U.S. and Europe do to combat it-unless they work together.. The U.S. and Europe are taking a stronger stance against China, but they don't agree on the best way to combat Beijing-and are therefore setting themselves up for failure. Absent uniform rules and a united opposition, Beijing will most likely ignore whatever either one sets forward.

title: Euthanasia And Organ Harvesting
summary: As lawful assisted suicide spreads, some advocates call for a monstrous expansion.. Euthanasia or physician-assisted suicide is legal in Switzerland, Holland and Belgium, as well as a growing number of U.S. states, including California, Colorado and most recently Maine, whose governor signed the Death With Dignity Act last week. New medical guidance in Canada, where the practice has been legal for three years for terminally ill patients, hints at the monstrous ways assisted suicide might be expanded in the coming years.

title: The Case for Restraint in the Gulf
summary: So long as U.S. ships aren't struck, Trump should stick with his current Iran strategy.. The latest crisis with Iran illustrates an important but widely neglected point about world politics: Amid all the talk about American decline, American power in the international system has actually grown. Even five years ago the U.S. could not force Iran out of world oil markets without causing a devastating spike in oil and gas prices that would destabilize the world economy. Today, world energy markets are so robust that Brent crude prices have fallen since the first set of attacks on oil tankers in May.

title: 'The Levelling' Review: Masters Versus the Masses
summary: In a world of populist discontent, the advice of elite policy experts can be both condescending and remarkably unhelpful.. Resentment of elites is the theme of the hour. In "The Levelling," Michael O'Sullivan mentions a historical analogy to make all the more vivid our current moment. In England in the late 1640s, he notes, a faction called the Levellers complained about the grandees in Oliver Cromwell's army, which had just defeated Charles I in a civil war. The grandees wanted to impose a postwar settlement without consulting the rank and file in the army. As one Leveller put it, calling for more equality: "Have you shook this nation like an earthquake to produce no more than this for us?"

title: Once More to Ground Zero
summary: I found a relaxed, sweet mood at a site I'd spent almost 18 years avoiding.. New York

title: No Millionaire's Tax in New Jersey Lawmakers' Proposed Budget
summary: Democratic leaders split with Gov. Phil Murphy, who campaigned on raising taxes on high earners. Democratic lawmakers in New Jersey introduced a budget that doesn't raise taxes on millionaires, setting up a standoff with Gov. Phil Murphy, who has made the issue one of his priorities.

title: A New Twist in the Fight Over NYC High-School Admissions Testing
summary: The students who receive a special designation allowing them extra time to take the elite public high schools are more often white or well off. The students who receive a special designation allowing them extra time to take the admissions exam to New York City's elite public high schools are more often white or well off, according to data released Monday by the city Department of Education.

title: Sports Illustrated Operating Rights Sold
summary: Under May deal, Meredith had been slated to publish print magazine and manage website. Sports Illustrated may be leaving the Meredith Corp. family after all.

title: MTA to Add More Officers to Subway to Stop Fare Evaders
summary: Fare evasion is on track to cost the authority $260 million this year, MTA's chairman said. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will deploy 500 officers to target fare evasion and assaults on New York City's subway and bus systems.

title: Trump Administration Is Split Over Arms Sale to Taiwan
summary: Some officials fear that the proposed $2 billion deal could hinder trade talks with China. WASHINGTON-As the U.S. pursues the sale of more than $2 billion of tanks and other weapons to Taiwan, the Trump administration is split over the potential repercussions the deal may have on efforts to reignite trade talks with China.

title: New York Lawmakers Near Landmark Deal on Greenhouse Gas Emissions
summary: Bill to mandate an 85% reduction by 2050 would be the most stringent in the country. New York state legislators on Monday reached a tentative deal on a landmark climate change bill that would set up the state to have the highest standards in the country for greenhouse gas emission reductions, lawmakers said.

title: Alex Jones Sent Lawyers for Sandy Hook Families Child Pornography, Flings Say
summary: Materials allegedly turned up amid filings in defamation lawsuit some family members of victims have filed against Jones. Far-right talk-show host Alex Jones sent child pornography to the legal team representing family members of victims killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School school in a defamation case against him, the attorneys said.

title: Gloria Vanderbilt, Heiress and Jeans Queen, Dies at 95
summary: Her death was announced by her journalist son, Anderson Cooper. Gloria Vanderbilt, the glamorous heiress, artist and fashion designer whose curve-hugging, name-brand jeans became a hit with women in the 1970s and '80s, died Monday at the age of 95.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Both Federal and State Prosecution for Same Act
summary: High court reaffirms past double-jeopardy rulings after several justices raised concerns in recent years. WASHINGTON-Resoundingly reaffirming its view of double jeopardy, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday that federal and state governments each can prosecute a defendant for the identical conduct despite the Constitution's bar against trying someone twice for the same crime.

title: Egypt's Ousted Islamist President Morsi Has Died
summary: Nation's only freely elected leader suffered a heart attack while attending a court session in an espionage trial. CAIRO-Egypt's former President Mohammed Morsi, an Islamist leader freely elected in the aftermath of the country's 2011 uprising, died on Monday after spending the past six years as a prisoner following the military coup that deposed him.

title: Quebec Bans Religious Garb on Public-Sector Employees
summary: Canadian province is first jurisdiction in North America to make such a prohibition, drawing criticism from Muslims and civil-rights groups. OTTAWA-Quebec will prohibit teachers, police officers and certain other public-sector employees from wearing religious symbols while on the job, making the French-speaking Canadian province the first North American jurisdiction in decades to enact such a ban.

title: FAA Seeks to Enable Return of Supersonic Passenger Aircraft
summary: Agency wants amended noise rules to foster testing of supersonic airliners and business jets. LE BOURGET, France-U.S. aviation regulators unveiled plans to ease noise restrictions for testing proposed supersonic commercial planes in American skies, part of a broader initiative to promote development of such technology.

title: A Company's Classics Take the Stage
summary: The acrobatic dance-theater group Pilobolus returns to the Joyce Theater with a program that leans heavily on vintage favorites..

title: West Virginia Considers Bill Penalizing Teachers Who Strike
summary: Legislation comes one year after educators won 5% pay rise in two-week protest. West Virginia lawmakers are considering legislation to penalize educators who go on strike a year after a statewide walkout ended with teachers getting a 5% raise.

title: Loan Market Splits Between 'Haves and Have-Nots'
summary: Investors force changes to some lower-rated loan sales. Some lower-rated businesses are being forced to pay up to complete new debt offerings even as others attract robust demand for their bonds and loans, a sign the debt market is bifurcating at a time of increased uncertainty about the economic outlook.

title: Louisiana's Medicaid Expansion a Success
summary: Medicaid expansion in Louisiana has been a great success. It has led to our state's uninsured rate among adults being reduced by half in just two years-from 22.7% in 2015 to 11.4% in 2017.. In his June 8 Cross Country piece "Medicaid Expansion Has Louisianans Dropping Private Plans," Chris Jacobs from the Pelican Institute presents incomplete data in a misleading way to convince readers that this isn't the case.

title: Don't Blame Doctors for Those Surprise Bills
summary: The real problem is that insurers completely control and determine rates paid to physicians.. Regarding Benedic Ippolito's "Get Rid of Surprise Medical Bills" (op-ed, June 12): When presented with a patient specimen, I don't wait in the laboratory to check the patient's insurance. I run the right tests and review the slides at my microscope to diagnose disease. The billing for the medical service comes much later. The notion that a pathologist may be out-of-network just so he or she can charge more for a patient's diagnosis defies current practice and ignores the health-insurance carrier's role in surprise billing.

title: Hard to Pick Immigrants for the Long Term
summary: The selective approach to immigration is tilted toward those who have had the advantages of life in their home countries. It ignores the fact that among the tired, poor "masses yearning to be free", there are latent talents that can grow and flourish when planted in the soil of an open society.. In his June 5 letter, Bruce Thatcher argues for an immigration policy that is strongly selective: "If, for example, we are going to be short x number of future engineers . . . we ought to seek like numbers of engineers . . . among new immigrants."

title: And What Would You Do?
summary: If my wife or child were in the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School building, what would I have done?. Regarding the letters "What Lesson From the Coward of Broward?" (June 12): Though I don't have all the details, had I been in Deputy Scot Peterson's place I would have had to ask myself a very tough question. If my wife or child were in the building, what would I have done? It isn't really that tough a question.

title: New Fundraising Channel for China Inc. Opens in London
summary: For the U.K., the initiative could help boost business with China and bolster London's financial-center credentials as Brexit looms. HONG KONG-Share-backed instruments from one of China's biggest brokerages began trading in Britain on Monday, under a just-launched program linking markets in Shanghai and London, but modest pricing for the more-than $1.5 billion deal suggested lukewarm interest from investors.

title: Target Outages Illustrate Retail's Growing Tech Complexity
summary: Technology maintenance is getting more complicated because systems are interconnected, causing ripple effects when problems arise. The technical problems at Target Corp. stores over the weekend illustrate the challenge of unifying a large retailer's technology infrastructure with its bricks-and-mortar presence and underscore the importance of having trusted vendors and backup plans.

title: 'Striking Power: Iconoclasm in Ancient Egypt' Review: Editing the Image
summary: An exhibition at the Pulitzer Arts Foundation looks at the violent impulse to destroy or deface representations of religious and political authority.. St. Louis

title: No Easy Fix for Legg Mason and Other Money Managers
summary: Pushback from affiliates shows how hard it can be for firms to streamline their businesses. The plan to fix money manager Legg Mason Inc. appears as obvious as ever-and no easier to pull off.

title: Blank-Check Boom Hits Snag
summary: The Big Board proposed relaxing rules related to special-purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs. The Securities and Exchange Commission is cooling off the race to bring more blank-check companies to U.S. investors, after a string of controversial episodes involving such firms.

title: White House Won't Invite Israeli Officials to Bahrain Conference
summary: U.S. is set to unveil economic part of its Israeli-Palestinian peace plan at the event. The White House said Monday it won't invite the Israeli government to the unveiling of the economic part of its Israeli-Palestinian peace plan at a Bahrain conference next week, dealing a set back to a signature initiative of President Trump.

title: Gulf of Oman Tanker Attacks Roil Mideast Oil Market
summary: Concerns over more hostile actions and higher rates keep some ships in ports, reflecting the new heightened risks of transporting crude. Days after attacks crippled two fuel tankers in the Gulf of Oman, fewer vessels were leaving ports and daily freight rates for oil supertankers were as much as 50% higher, shipping brokers and tanker owners said, reflecting the new heightened risks of transporting crude through Middle Eastern waters.

title: Stocks Climb Ahead of Central-Bank Meetings
summary: Main focus will be on the Fed, whose members are likely to debate an interest-rate cut. U.S. stocks edged higher ahead of central bank policy meetings around the world as investors continue to bet the Federal Reserve will slash interest rates this year.

title: Ripple to Invest Up to $50 Million in MoneyGram
summary: The deal is an extension of the initial agreement for MoneyGram to use Ripple's XRP cryptocurrency. Ripple Inc., a startup behind the XRP cryptocurrency, agreed to invest up to $50 million in MoneyGram International Inc. in a deal that stands to rank among the first crypto-based company investments in a major U.S. publicly listed firm.

title: Supreme Court Backs Virginia Ban on Uranium Mining
summary: Justices, in splintered ruling, affirm the power of states to regulate mining on private lands. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Monday upheld a Virginia law that prohibits uranium mining within the commonwealth's borders, in a splintered ruling that affirmed the powers of the states to regulate mining on private lands within their territories.

title: Oil's Slide Highlights Global-Growth Fears
summary: Breakdown in U.S.-China trade talks has also hit demand for other commodities, like copper and cotton. Oil prices have remained soft this month despite rising geopolitical tensions and threats of supply disruptions, the latest sign that investors fear trade friction will hit global growth and sap demand for crude.

title: We Blamed George W. Bush
summary: NBC/WSJ poll suggests Trump is not especially partisan.. Given the volume of commentary describing Donald Trump as a uniquely polarizing figure-and the amount of time Democrats spend attempting to end his presidency-one might think he is among the most partisan Presidents in our history. But that's not the message in the latest NBC/Wall Street Journal survey.

title: Meat Producers Hit on Flooding Concerns
summary: Persistent wet weather in U.S. threatens to increase soybean and corn costs for Tyson Foods, others. U.S. meat producers' pain worsened Monday, as their shares were hurt by fears about how persistent flooding is affecting crops they rely on for feed.

title: Motor-Vehicle Fatalities Down Slightly in 2018
summary: NHTSA estimate finds roughly a 1% drop in deaths from a year earlier. WASHINGTON-An estimated 36,760 people died in motor-vehicle crashes last year, about a 1% decrease from the year before, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's Early Estimates of Motor Vehicle Fatalities in 2018.

title: Guatemala Presidential Election Heads to Runoff
summary: Low first-round turnout at source of migrant wave shows pessimism over economy, corruption. Guatemala's presidential election is headed for an August runoff between an ex-first lady and a former prisons director, after Sunday's first round of voting in an impoverished country at the center of a regional migration crisis.

title: Harvard Rescinds Parkland Shooting Survivor's Admission Over Racist Texts
summary: Kyle Kashuv, who advocated for gun rights after the school shooting, called his past remarks 'abhorrent'. A student who survived the 2018 mass school shooting in Parkland, Fla., and went on to become an outspoken advocate for gun rights said Harvard University rescinded his admission earlier this month after his past racist remarks came to light.

title: Pfizer to Buy Array BioPharma
summary: Acquisition adds to streak of deals by pharmaceutical companies looking to bolster cancer treatment portfolios. Pfizer Inc. agreed to buy Array BioPharma Inc. for $10.64 billion in cash, as one of the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies seeks to expand its cancer lineup with targeted therapies.

title: Growth Fears Override Supply Squeeze for Beaten-Down Copper
summary: A strike at a huge Chilean mine failed to entice investors to bet on the growth-sensitive metal. A work stoppage at a huge Chilean mine has failed to boost copper prices, indicating that investors are wary of betting on growth-sensitive commodities ahead of the G-20 summit in Japan in late June.

title: Roller-Coaster Designer on the Ups and Downs of His Job
summary: As an architect by training, Jeff Havlik delivers for thrillseekers around the world. Millions of people ride roller coasters every year, paying to defy gravity and good sense. Many of those thrillseekers climb aboard the dozens of coasters designed by Jeff Havlik of PGAV Destinations, a St. Louis architecture firm that specializes in theme parks, museums, visitor centers, aquariums and other entertainment experiences.

title: Meetings Give U.S. and India a Chance to Get Past Irritants
summary: A Trump-Modi encounter and a Pompeo visit offer opportunities to move beyond trade tensions. NEW DELHI-After more than a decade of growing ties, the U.S. and India have suddenly hit a rough patch, a challenge for Washington's efforts to cultivate the world's largest democracy as a critical counterweight to China.

title: Photos: A Look Back at Gloria Vanderbilt's Life
summary: Scenes from Ms. Vanderbilt's life at home, work and on the town. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: KPMG Agrees to Pay $50 Million Penalty Tied to Misconduct Allegations
summary: An outside consultant will check the accounting firm's internal policies related to ethics. KPMG LLP agreed to pay $50 million to settle allegations that former employees got an unlawful sneak peek at regulators' plans to inspect its work and auditors at the firm cheated on internal training exams.

title: China's President Xi to Make First State Visit to North Korea
summary: Trip could bolster Beijing's bargaining position ahead of possible summit with U.S.. BEIJING-China said President Xi Jinping will make his first state visit to North Korea this week, a trip seen as bolstering Beijing's bargaining position ahead of a possible summit with the U.S.

title: Boeing's New Long-Haul Jet Faces Delay
summary: Customers for Boeing's new long-haul jet are planning for delivery delays. LE BOURGET, France- General Electric Co. is having to redesign an engine part for Boeing Co. 's new 777X long-haul jetliner, meaning a delay for its first test flight and potentially for the first delivery of the plane to airline customers.

title: Clap, Clap, Clap! Sly Rebellion From U.S. Women's Soccer
summary: The U.S. women's soccer team offers an impish riposte after a celebration controversy. Let's please move on.. The sports world is not typically clever. I'm sorry, sports world, but it's true.

title: Why GDPR Has Been a Boon for Google and Facebook
summary: Europe's privacy laws have pushed advertisers to give business to the tech giants they trust. Europe's new privacy law appears to be helping tech giants-for now.

title: San Francisco Fed Wants to Reward Banks for Climate-Change Loans
summary: Paper says banks can get extra credit for climate-adaptation loans under Community Reinvestment Act. The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco wants banks to get extra credit for making loans that help communities adapt to climate change and prepare for future natural disasters.

title: German Terror Police Probe Politician's Killing
summary: A man has been arrested in connection with the fatal shooting of Walter Lübcke, who supported Merkel's welcoming of refugees. BERLIN-German federal prosecutors are investigating a possible ideological motive in the killing of a politician who defended the government's welcoming of refugees, adding to concerns about a resurgence of political violence in the country.

title: Sotheby's Deal is Art for Art's Sake
summary: Cable billionaire Patrick Drahi isn't buying the New York auction house for financial reasons. Sotheby's can relax. Patrick Drahi is buying art for art's sake.

title: Real-Estate Stocks Rise To New Highs
summary: The steady dividend payers benefit from falling rates as well as bets on warehouse operators. Real-estate stocks are on a tear in 2019, beneficiaries of the surprising fall in interest rates as well as bets on the future of e-commerce.

title: Vanessa Carlton Is the New Carole King. Here's the First Time They Met
summary: Best known for her 2001 hit 'A Thousand Miles,' the singer-songwriter is signed up to play King in the jukebox musical 'Beautiful.' Carlton uncovers their 20-year-old cassette of music together. "I don't know a lot of people who would be like, 'I hate Carole King,'" Vanessa Carlton says, of the woman she's about to portray on stage. "Those people don't exist, do they?"

title: Does 'Sustainable Fashion' Really Mean Anything?
summary: At the Italian clothing trade show Pitti Uomo, our men's fashion columnist explores manifestations of everyone's favorite eco-friendly buzz word. "Sustainability" was the buzziest buzzword in the air during last week's edition of Pitti Uomo, the world's largest men's fashion trade show, in Florence, Italy. As I navigated countless rows of designers' booths, those pitching the clothes hurled the word at me again and again in reference to pieces that otherwise had no similarity. At Woolrich, the 189-year-old Italian-based outerwear brand, it was applied to the development of hood linings made of corn, in faux-fur form. At Far Afield, a British outfit, the word described a jolly pair of citrus-patterned swim trunks constructed from recycled water bottles. The word cropped up again at a Spanish label called IOweYou, my favorite discovery of the fair, which was peddling handsome sport coats and trousers in naturally dyed organic Indian cotton.

title: Trump Focuses Campaign Hopes on Florida
summary: President has acute interest in perennial battleground state but Democrats are eager to win it back. Backstage at a rally last month in Panama City Beach, Fla., President Trump unveiled a poll hidden inside his jacket that he said showed him winning the state. "How we doing?" he asked his team. "Are we going to win?"

title: Growth Is Worth Paying Up for at Pfizer
summary: A $10 billion price tag for cancer development is a reasonable risk for Pfizer to take. A fact of life for health-care companies, as well as patients: Good health care costs money.

title: How Privacy Rules Will Affect the Ad Industry in the Next Few Years
summary: The Wall Street Journal asked major players from across the industry about the impact of the new regulations. Here are their predictions.. This year companies are expected to spend $333 billion globally on online advertising, with plenty of that spending driven by advertisers' ability to target consumers based on their web-browsing histories, physical location, app usage, income levels and other information.

title: Huawei Expects $30 Billion Revenue Hit From U.S. Clampdown
summary: It is the first time the Chinese tech giant has quantified the potential impact of American actions against it. The U.S. campaign against Huawei Technologies Co. is taking a toll, with the company's founder forecasting a hit to revenue of about $30 billion this year and next.

title: Airbus Jumps Ahead of Boeing in Midsize-Plane Battle
summary: European plane maker's new jetliner aims to open trans-Atlantic service to smaller cities. PARIS- Airbus SE said it will develop its longest-range single-aisle plane yet, adding pressure on U.S. rival Boeing Co. , which plans a jet for the same market but is distracted by its 737 MAX crisis.

title: How Summer's Biggest Zombie Movie Got Its Cast
summary: Casting director Ellen Lewis on putting together an ensemble of A-listers that includes Adam Driver, Bill Murray, Chloë Sevigny, Selena Gomez, Danny Glover and (many, many) more. Director Jim Jarmusch's horror comedy The Dead Don't Die portrays the small town of Centerville, USA as its residents deal with a zombie attack-a result of the government's "polar fracking" throwing the earth off its axis. In the process of fighting the undead (or at least giving it their best effort), swords are wielded, the fourth wall is broken and Adam Driver crumples his 6' 2" frame into a teeny Smart car.

title: 'Who Cares?' Rich Unknowns Try Celebrity Tricks to Hide House Hunting
summary: As cameras and social media keep tabs on every neighborhood, more property buyers and sellers are turning to disguises, fake names, blindfolds. Real-estate agent Antonio del Rosario spent $400 one afternoon shepherding a Tony-winning actress through four New York City apartments.

title: The Small-School Strivers Landing Big Jobs
summary: Ivy Leaguers tend to sail into high-paying jobs-but there are ways to stand out without an elite college on your résumé. If the college-admissions scandal is any guide, attending an elite college is a ticket to a high-paying job. So what about students at lesser-known colleges, with names few people even recognize?

title: Introducing Anne Frank to a New Generation
summary: The collected writings of Anne Frank, the teenager whose diary became a symbol of resilience amid the Holocaust, will be published this month, when the author would have turned 90. Ten months before dying in Bergen-Belsen concentration camp at age 15, Anne Frank wrote in her soon-to-be-famous diary "I want to go on living even after my death!"

title: Lawmakers Propose Bills to Strengthen New Jersey's Sexual-Misconduct Response
summary: Legislation follows an investigation into how Gov. Phil Murphy's administration handled assault allegation against a state employee.

title: Hong Kong Leader Faces Growing Pressure to Resign After Protests
summary: The chief executive's future, extradition bill dominated discussions at an extraordinary meeting of the city's Executive Council on Monday. HONG KONG-Pressure mounted on Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam as protesters called for her to step down and members of her cabinet urged her to personally respond, a day after a mass rally triggered by her handling of a contentious extradition bill.

title: Democrats' Impeachment Answer Doesn't Get Any Easier
summary: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez says frustration with Democratic leadership's opposition to impeachment is 'quite real'. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: What Lies Behind Rising U.S.-Iran Tensions
summary: Iran is gambling that a threat to break out of the nuclear deal will unite the international community behind it rather than against it. Iran's announcement Monday that it is stepping up uranium enrichment frames almost perfectly the real story behind the rapidly escalating tensions in the Persian Gulf region. What the world is seeing isn't so much a march toward war, but rather a battle for leverage: the considerable leverage the Trump administration has gained over Iran on the one hand, and, on the other, the leverage Iran feels it badly needs to acquire over the U.S. to balance the score.

title: Strong Returns Lift Pay for Software CEOs
summary: PayPal's Daniel Schulman tops list that also includes Marc Benioff, Ginni Rometty and an $86,000 watch. PayPal Holdings Inc.'s Daniel Schulman collected a pay package totaling $37.8 million in 2018, making him one of the highest-paid bosses in the S&P 500. But for Mr. Schulman and many of his fellow CEOs in the software industry, big paydays were backed by healthy returns.

title: Pentagon to Set Up Marketplace Linking Suppliers With Trusted Investors
summary: Move is the latest step to sideline Chinese entities from U.S. security institutions. LE BOURGET, France-The Pentagon plans to mandate stronger cyber defenses for its suppliers and help bolster the balance sheet of some financially struggling vendors amid concern China could exploit their weakness to access critical technologies.

title: Bitter Reality Is Setting in for Europe's Airlines
summary: Lufthansa's profit warning showcases European carriers' vulnerability compared with U.S. peers. So much for hopes that European airlines will finally put their house in order and rival the profitability of U.S. peers. A big profit warning from Lufthansa -the top European carrier by passengers-is the latest sign that this won't happen anytime soon.

title: Stocks to Watch: Dish Network, Chewy, Home Depot, Pfizer and More
summary: Texas Instruments, Amazon.com and Keane Group are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Monday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Monday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Forget the Mall, Shoppers Are Buying Gucci at Airports
summary: From $38 lipstick to $400 Scotch, makers of luxury goods find fliers willing to splurge during 'golden hour' before their flight. Makers of luxury goods from liquor to perfume think they have found the antidote to the fading American shopping mall: airport terminals.

title: Collective Health Raises $205 Million in SoftBank-Led Funding Round
summary: Health-benefits platform marks the Vision Fund's first health-care services investment. SoftBank Group has made its first foray into health-care services, leading a $205 million investment in Collective Health Inc.

title: Chinese Regulators Try to Calm Fears of a Funding Squeeze
summary: Securities regulator asks brokerages and asset-management firms not to cut off dealings with smaller banks. Chinese regulators made fresh attempts to calm frayed nerves in the country's financial sector, as bank liquidity remained tight by some measures three weeks after authorities took over a struggling city lender.

title: Brexit Strikes a Bum Note for U.K. Artists as EU Gigs Dry Up
summary: A no-deal departure from Europe would mean touring musicians could face logistical headaches. LONDON-For the U.K.'s legions of musicians, from jobbing French horn players to stars of opera and the indie scene, a no-deal Brexit hits a bum note.

title: Fed Stimulus Just Ain't What It Used to Be
summary: Federal Reserve may cut rates soon, but its efforts may have less oomph due to changes in the U.S. economy. Unnerved by mounting risks to the U.S. economy, the Federal Reserve is considering lowering interest rates. Rate cuts might not provide the economy with as much oomph as in the past, though.

title: Anthony Davis, the Lakers and the Battle for the Future of the NBA
summary: The Warriors' dynasty might be over. Anthony Davis is teammates with LeBron James. For the first time in years, the league is now wide open.. One of the wildest off-seasons the NBA might ever see began long before the actual NBA season was over.

title: Google Pays for Big Tech's Sins
summary: Alphabet shares have lagged behind other tech stocks heading into contentious annual meeting. Google is hardly the only giant tech company in hot water these days, but its investors could be forgiven for feeling otherwise.

title: Vatican Calls for Consideration of Married Priests in Remote Amazon
summary: In a new document, the Vatican says the church should consider allowing women to perform 'official ministry'. ROME-The Catholic Church should study the possibility of ordaining married men to serve as priests in remote parts of South America's Amazon region, where many parishes have struggled to recruit clergy, the Vatican said in a document released on Monday.

title: U.S. Women's Soccer Games Outearned Men's Games
summary: The 2015 World Cup title was a catalyst to boost women's game revenues, which in recent years exceeded the men's. PARIS-In the three years after the U.S. women's soccer team won the 2015 World Cup, U.S. women's games generated more total revenue than U.S. men's games, according to audited financial reports from the U.S. Soccer Federation.

title: Mexican Shelters Strained by Migrants Struggle With U.S. Returnees
summary: People sent back to Mexico to await asylum claims increase pressure on social services. TIJUANA, Mexico-The last place Honduran migrant Gustavo Edil Gutiérrez imagined himself was back in Tijuana, living in a shelter and losing hope as he awaits his U.S. asylum hearing across the border.

title: Google's Ad Dominance Explained in Three Charts
summary: Tech giant is the leading supplier of services to carry out virtually every step of purchasing and selling ads. Google is the dominant player in online advertising, one reason the U.S. Justice Department is laying the groundwork for potential antitrust action against the tech giant. It has a 37% share of the $130 billion U.S. digital ad market, according to research firm eMarketer, but understanding Google's full clout requires a deeper look at the sector.

title: Fed Faces Unfamiliar Dilemma With Rate Projections
summary: The so-called dot plot hasn't existed during a period when markets expected the central bank's next move would be to cut rates, and not to raise them. Federal Reserve officials are moving into unfamiliar territory with their dots.

summary: Red flags for parents include disruptions in kids' sleep, socializing and outside interests. Twitch. Fortnite. Netflix.

title: Questions Over Drivers and Wine Storage Push Out Senior ANZ Executive
summary: Review concludes characterization of expenses by head of bank's New Zealand operation fell short of internal standards. summary: Narrow spreads are one factor giving confidence to stock investors as they push indexes closer to records. title: China's Economy Shows Fresh Signs of Weakness
summary: Lost momentum reflects battered sentiment stemming from the Trump administration's tariffs on Chinese exports. title: The Best Financial Advice I Ever Got
summary: We asked financial experts to tell us the piece of guidance that has made the biggest difference in their lives. There's no shortage of financial advice out there.

title: Looking for a Road Map for Retirement? Good Luck With That
summary: Everybody has lots of advice on how to live a fulfilling life after leaving work. I've learned it isn't worth much.. When I retired from a 38-year journalism career in 2017, I was bombarded with advice from close friends, not-so-close friends and even complete strangers, some of whom I met while standing in line at my local Social Security office.

title: Two Ways to Simplify Your Student-Loan Debt
summary: Borrowers often consolidate or refinance. Here's how to compare the two options. Managing student-loan repayment can be tricky, especially for those who have multiple school loans and multiple servicers.

title: What You Need to Know About Capital-Gains Taxes (but Probably Don't)
summary: The law is a lot more complicated than many people think. By tax-law standards, the rules on capital-gains taxes may appear fairly straightforward, especially for taxpayers who qualify for a zero-percent rate.

title: How Charities Can Use 'Tipping Points' to Get You to Donate More
summary: Being told you could be the person who takes a fundraising campaign over the top is a powerful motivator. Consider how likely you would be to donate to a charity that made this appeal as part of its fundraising effort: "We are hoping to get 75% participation in this campaign."

title: Game Plan: A Single Mother Seeks to Shore Up Her Finances
summary: This hair stylist has learned to live on less. Now she is ready to take on more work and start saving for retirement.. After struggling financially for several years, Natalie Berglund, a personal hair stylist and single mother of two girls, realized something recently: She is ready to think longer term.

title: What's a Lemon From George Washington's Tree Really Worth?
summary: For collectors of iconic objects, the tricky part is putting a price on history. A fresh lemon can be purchased for less than $1. But in 2008, Cowan's Auctions in Cincinnati sold a lemon blackened with age for $2,350.

title: Gary Woodland Wins U.S. Open
summary: The 35-year-old American takes his first career major after holding off a charge by two-time defending champion Brooks Koepka. PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.-When Gary Woodland walks around a golf course, fans are often highly excited to see him. This is an odd thing for a little-known PGA Tour veteran. As Woodland has learned, there is a reason: They think he is Brooks Koepka.

title: Target Stores Hit by Technical Snafus Over Weekend
summary: Retailer says incidents with checkout systems on Saturday and Sunday weren't caused by cyberattack. Technical problems at Target Corp. stores this weekend frustrated shoppers, who were unable to make purchases for two hours on Saturday or use a credit card at some stores on Sunday.

title: Hong Kong Upheaval Puts Beijing in a Bind
summary: Resume Subscription. HONG KONG - An attempt by Hong Kong's leader to push a Beijing-backed extradition bill galvanized unprecedented resistance to tighter mainland control, presenting Chinese President Xi Jinping with the most high-profile challenge yet to his authority.
